docs.lead_paragraph: Wall Street, long known as a clubby man's world, has long sought to shed its reputation as a land of Gordon Gekko wannabes. For more than a decade, firms like Goldman Sachs, Morgan Stanley and Lehman Brothers have not just opened their doors to women but actively seek them out.

headline.main: Wall Street's Women Face a Fork in the Road

docs.lead_paragraph: Shame, stigma and the pathologies of intimate relationships are the new frontier in the fight against AIDS in Africa. How do you treat what is lodged in people’s minds?

docs.lead_paragraph: ANA was 14 when she and her parents, in from Connecticut, spent the night at my Brooklyn apartment -- 14 years old, and more than 20 weeks pregnant. When I went into the den to let Ana's father know that I had pulled out the living-room couch for him, all three -- father, mother, daughter -- were lined up shoulder-to-shoulder on the sofa bed like a child's collection of dolls, nestled close, asleep. The next morning, my husband took them all to the abortion clinic, together. Ana's family is among the many people my husband and I have played host to as members of an organization called the Haven Coalition. We regularly get calls from the coalition asking us if we can provide free overnight housing to women coming to New York from surrounding states for the later-term abortions that are rarely available to them closer to home. For privacy reasons, we operate on a first-name basis. We are told how old the woman is and how far along she is in her pregnancy, if anyone is accompanying her and at which clinic we should pick her up and drop her off.
docs.abstract: Op-Ed article by Lynn Harris, member of Haven Coalition, organization that offers free overnight housing to women coming to New York for late-term abortions; opposes Child Custody Protection Act, passed by US Senate, that would make it federal crime to help under-age girls escape parental notification laws by crossing state lines to obtain abortion; contends parental involvement laws, on books in 34 states, put already at-risk girls in greater danger
docs.snippet: ANA was 14 when she and her parents, in from Connecticut, spent the night at my Brooklyn apartment -- 14 years old, and more than 20 weeks pregnant. When I went into the den to let Ana's father know that I had pulled out the living-room couch for...
